description:
'''Post-punk revival''' (also known as '''indie rock revival''' or '''garage rock revival''') is a [[Music genre|subgenre]] of [[indie rock]], as well as a musical scene and movement that emerged in the early 2000s. Originating as a stripped-down and back-to-basics version of [[Guitar-rock|guitar rock]] inspired by the original sounds and aesthetics of [[post-punk]], [[New wave music|new wave]] and [[garage rock]], the movement became closely associated with the [[new wave revival]] and [[garage rock revival]]. 

The genre has an emphasis on "rock authenticity" that was seen as a reaction to the commercialism of [[MTV]]-oriented [[nu metal]], [[hip hop music|hip hop]] and "bland" [[post-Britpop]] groups. The commercial breakthrough of the genre came with the release of [[the Strokes]]' ''[[Is This It]]'' and [[the White Stripes]]' [[White Blood Cells|''White Blood Cells'']], both in 2001. The genre reached a zenith in the middle of the decade with the success of [[Bloc Party]], [[Arctic Monkeys]], [[the Killers]], and [[Yeah Yeah Yeahs]]. Over time, later indie and post-punk bands were criticized with the term "[[landfill indie]]".
